{"position": null, "sentence": "Typically, interactive behaviors have three properties: P1: what triggers the interactive behavior, P2: the visual state changes made to the GUI by the interactive behaviors, and  P3: non-visible states and relationships that may affect current and future behaviors.  For instance, in a game setting when Super Mario bounces on a turtle, the end-user's verbal description could be: \u201cWhen Super Mario jumps and lands on top of an enemy turtle [P1], the turtle should flip upside down, and hide its head and legs in the shell [P2]; the shell can then be used as a weapon once it lands on the ground [P3]\u201d.  The interactive behavior here includes interaction (button press) state recognition (triggering condition: Mario bouncing on the turtle), animated behavior (turtle flipping and hiding), and abstract relationships (gravity, behavior conditions).  Variation makes automating and composing such interactive behaviors difficult without programming (where the time and effort required is inappropriate for early prototyping).  However,  it is relatively easy for a crowd worker to understand the triggering condition (P1)", "statisticType": "other", "record": {"pval": "1"}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "Although P6 did not feel as though the app had impacted their ability, all the other interviewers said it had some form of impact: either in the short-term (for example P5 saying that the \u201cpressure\" from knowing they were being recorded made them \u201cthink a lot more\" on smooth technique) or the long term (P1 saying they were \u201cclimbing better\" after using the app).        * With all of the interviewees being within my target demographic, all saying they enjoyed using the app, and four out of six of the interviewees saying that they are definitely going to continue using the app in the future, it can be concluded that the app is popular among the type of climbers I was aiming to develop it for.        * The smoothness score definitely enabled fun, with P3 saying that they \u201cloved the gamification, wanting to get the scores as high or as low as possible, that is quite good fun\", yet some interviewees who saw the app as more of an analytics tool \u201chadn\u2019t really considered treating it like a game to try and get a better score\"(P1)", "statisticType": "other", "record": {"pval": "1"}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "Others, however, found it aesthetically pleasing (\u201cI just liked Facebook more\u2026 it felt more\u2026 I mean it felt more Nordic, it wasn't grey and boring, it was white and nice\u2026\u201d, P30) and wanted it to persist (\u201cis there a way that I can keep the background white?\u201d, P15).  rq1-amount-of-use-how-do-goal-reminders-or-removing-the-newsfeed-impact-time-spent-and-visits-made    \u00a7.\u00a7 RQ1 (Amount of use): How do goal reminders or removing the newsfeed impact time spent and visits made? {"position": null, "sentence": "In Cno-feed, participants said the intervention stopped unintended behaviours from being triggered in the first place (\u201cthere is nothing here [referring to the newsfeed], like `what did I want?', you know, so then I went and contacted the person or looked at the specific thing that I wanted, not what I saw and kinda wanted at the moment\u201d, P56interview).  At the same time, there were downsides to the interventions in that Cgoal was frequently annoying or frustrating, especially because it was not sensitive to context (\u201cI use facebook just to message people and I found this extremely annoying because I need to tell someone something and then this thing comes up and I'd just get annoyed\u2026\u201d P32interview), and that Cno-feed led to fear of missing out (\u201cmissing out on a lot because actually a lot of the ways I interact with people on facebook is things I see on the newsfeed\u201d, P12interview).  3 cross-device-use     \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Cross-device use   When asked if the interventions changed how they used Facebook on smartphone vs laptop, 86% of participants in Cgoal and 57% in Cno-feed answered `Yes' (compared to 6% in Ccontrol, \u03c7^2 = 65.19, p  0.001).  Unpacking this in the qualitative data, participants in both experimental conditions expressed that cross-device access helped them manage the interventions' downsides, while still enjoying the positive effects (\u201cif I was scrolling through the newsfeed or checking events, then it wouldn't be annoying because I shouldn't be doing that on my laptop while I'm working, and if it was something like sending messages about work, contacting friends and asking for help then I could use my phone\u201d, P40goal_interview; \u201cI could reap the benefits of the newsfeed but without being sucked into it on two platforms\u201d, P28no-feed_survey), and so they sometimes used their smartphone for activities on Facebook the interventions interfered with, but as a more deliberate choice (\u201cyou're working on your laptop, uhm, and then it's very easy to just click new tab, but having to get your phone out\u2026\u201d, P19goal_interview; \u201cthe time I did spend on my phone was more, like, focused because I was actually looking for things I missed out on on my laptop\u201d, P55no-feed_interview).  rq4-post-intervention-effects-do-the-effects-rq1-3-of-goal-reminders-or-removing-the-newsfeed-persist-after-interventions-are-removed    \u00a7.\u00a7 RQ4 (Post-intervention effects): Do the effects (RQ1-3) of goal reminders or removing the newsfeed persist after interventions are removed?   Comparing post-intervention to baseline, Cgoal and Cno-feed were associated with some persisting effects, with participants in Cgoal engaging in fewer daily visits and some feeling that the intervention helped build a habit of more intentional use, and participants in Cno-feed engaging in less passive newsfeed browsing.  Thus, in terms of amount of use, participants in Cgoal made fewer daily visits post-intervention compared to baseline (median number of daily visits in first baseline = 29.4, median in post-intervention block = 9.8, p = 0.003, r = 0.72", "statisticType": "other", "record": {"pval": null}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "Our thematic analysis revealed 4 specific types of integration barriers that described how these difficulties occurred:  understanding, mapping, modification, and testing barriers, discussed below.     Understanding Barrier: How do I use an unfamiliar code block?   Understanding barriers occurs when students encounter unfamiliar code blocks in an example, e.g., P2 found a \u201cglide\u201d block that they were unfamiliar with and asked \u201cWhat is the glide [block]?\u201d (P2)", "statisticType": "other", "record": {"pval": "2"}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "In addition to not understanding a new API, students may also experience doubts about the usage of the API in the context of the example:  \u201cI don't know how this will work with the broadcast start timer\u201d (P3)", "statisticType": "other", "record": {"pval": "3"}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "A system could also proactively show or link to documentation on unfamiliar concepts that students have likely not encountered before.       Mapping Barrier: How do I map a property of the example code to my own code?   Students encountered mapping barriers when trying to understand which parts of the example corresponded to existing parts of their own code, such as sprites \u2014 P3 explained not knowing whether the example code should go into their current sprite or a new sprite: \u201cI don't know if creating another sprite is necessary.\u201d; P5, when working with a multi-sprite example, had mistakenly copied example code to the wrong sprite, and later acknowledged that \u201cAny difficulties that I might have had were... taking some time to understand how to change sprites to fit my project.\u201d (P5)", "statisticType": "other", "record": {"pval": "5"}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "The student gave up using the example because they were unable to modify the example to turn the correct number of degrees: \u201cWe were going to stick to what the code said, but the ball keeps falling off the paddle and we didn't know how to fix that, so I'm trying new stuff.\u201d (P2)", "statisticType": "other", "record": {"pval": "2"}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "During our interview, two students asked the interviewer about how to test the example code immediately after the student has opened the example (e.g.,  \u201cIs there anywhere to see how the code actually works in the example?\u201d (P1)", "statisticType": "other", "record": {"pval": "1"}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "In Section\u00a0<ref>, we discuss some approaches to mitigate these memorability-related challenges.         \u00a7.\u00a7 PINs and Past Relationships  Park et al.\u00a0<cit.> conducted an online survey and found that, among other factors, marriage and co-habitation results in the sharing of online accounts.  Our findings are congruent with theirs.   Our participants self-reported wide-spread sharing of PINs with their romantic partners.   Nine participants reported sharing their digital PINs with someone that they were in a romantic relationship with in the past.  Three of these participants did not change the PIN because they either still trusted that person or they felt there was no need since the other person no longer had access to assets (\u201c[I] changed it just for more privacy but didn\u2019t feel the need to change it.\u201d (P6)", "statisticType": "other", "record": {"pval": "6"}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "Other participants updated their PINs, although one participant reported that there was no need to do so (\u201c[Did] nothing as I had the device\u201d (P3)", "statisticType": "other", "record": {"pval": "3"}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}
{"position": null, "sentence": "We later excluded one participant (P9)", "statisticType": "other", "record": {"pval": "9"}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "When asked about the difficulties they faced in speaking actively, many parents reflected that they often could not quickly think of, and lead the child into, new situations  where different words can be applied. \u201cI don't know Korean well, so [I just say]  just throw it! Throw it! \u2026The only word I could come up  with [the ball] was \u201cthrow\u201d. (P6)", "statisticType": "other", "record": {"pval": "6"}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "P4 shared that  \"many parents  of multicultural families in Korea are worried that  their incorrect pronunciation will have a negative  effect on their children\" (P4)", "statisticType": "other", "record": {"pval": "4"}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "This limitation is discussed further in Section <ref>.  To improve the usability of , participants suggest its interface could benefit from the addition of direct manipulation features, such as selecting and manually transforming objects in the scene: \u201cI think that I would maybe change how different items are selected in order to change of modify an object in the picture. (P33); \u201cmaybe there should be a move function, where we keep the drawing the same but move it\u201d (P40).  Moreover, some participants also recommended adding an undo feature, \u201cMaybe a separate button to get back\u201d (P31), or the ability to manually invoke to redraw an object, \u201cI'd like a way to ask the computer to redraw a specific object\u201d (P3)", "statisticType": "other", "record": {"pval": "3"}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "Other participants used praise between their sketching instructions, which could be used as a cue to preserve the sketch output and guide further iteration: \u201c\u2026Draw an airplane, Good try, Draw a table \u2026\u201d (P1)", "statisticType": "other", "record": {"pval": "1"}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "We did not observe any asymmetrical effects <cit.>.       Holm-Bonferroni adjusted post-hoc testing revealed that there were significant differences between each level for target distance (p < 0.001, as expected), map size (p < 0.001, as expected) and between baseline (mean target acquisition time over all map sizes and target distances: 59.62 seconds, sd = 23.95) and 3D Navigation (mean target acquisition time over all map sizes and target distances: 33.52 seconds, sd = 8.10) (p < 0.001)", "statisticType": "other", "record": {"pval": "0.001"}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "While teams in human-human-AI and human-AI-AI conditions performed equally (p = .948)", "statisticType": "other", "record": {"pval": null}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "All three other conditions did not differ on team situation awareness: AI-only vs human-AI-AI (p = .37)", "statisticType": "other", "record": {"pval": null}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "All three other conditions did not differ on team situation awareness: AI-only vs human-AI-AI  RPLUS MATCH , AI-only vs human-human-AI (p = .69)", "statisticType": "other", "record": {"pval": null}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "On the other hand, the team score is expected to decrease by 0.26 for every standard deviation increase in the team environment; however, these findings did not reach significance (p = .054)", "statisticType": "other", "record": {"pval": null}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "Again, given the strength of the model, the coefficients were regularized into beta coefficients. {"position": null, "sentence": "Lastly, team situational awareness is expected to decrease by 0.49 for every standard deviation increase in team interaction (p = 0.01)", "statisticType": "other", "record": {"pval": "0.01"}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "But not all participants understood what was happening and we can't ensure that the effectiveness would be as high for verification if it is not mandatory.] The application was designed in order to be easy-to-use and responding to users' expectations, and we can argue that it is the linearity of the vote casting in the Selene implementation that leads to this excellent result.  The quality of this straightforward behaviour was mentioned several times by participants, e.g. \"we follow the workflow but we can't really make a mistake\" (P3)", "statisticType": "other", "record": {"pval": "3"}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "In particular, participants mentioned the advantage of being able to vote at home, as other people won't influence them: \"Here I don't have interactions with other people\" (P5)", "statisticType": "other", "record": {"pval": "5"}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "In particular, participants mentioned the advantage of being able to vote at home, as other people won't influence them: \"Here I don't have interactions with other people\"  RPLUS MATCH , or \"I am sure to make my own choice [...] I feel less pressure than in polling station, with people behind\" (P2)", "statisticType": "other", "record": {"pval": "2"}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "Participants refer to some trusted third party to emphasize their own trust: \"if it is done by an authority, I will trust it\" (P2)", "statisticType": "other", "record": {"pval": "2"}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "They rejected the verification process arguing with their trust in the authority: \"If I trust the application I don't see why we should verify that the vote has been taken into account\" (P12).  Some participants expressed a built-in trust, e.g. \"I always trust technology\" (P14) or \"I trust it as I would trust any mobile applications\".  A verification impact was raised, mostly decreasing trust, e.g. \"I don't trust the application after verification, even if the tracking number is private\" (P33), even though an opposite positive effect on trust was also mentioned by some users: \"the second phase makes me feel secure\" (P4)", "statisticType": "other", "record": {"pval": "4"}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "But they expressed their [lack of] understanding in the process of verification: \"I feel in control maybe because I can see what I did, I can see my vote again\" (P11) or on the contrary \"I wonder why this is here, seeing results with percentages is enough for me\" (P3)", "statisticType": "other", "record": {"pval": "3"}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "However, many participants did not manage to provide a complete description of the verification phase after using the app.  Furthermore, the tracking number has not always been understood as such, but rather as a counting of votes: \"We can see our candidate and the number of people who voted for him\" (P6)", "statisticType": "other", "record": {"pval": "6"}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "LEDs (n=2).  Several participants noted that the physical coverage increased trustworthiness because it made the system more robust against hackers (concerns:hacking, n=3) than LEDs.  Concluding, the usage of physical occlusion could increase perceived safety and, thus, could be considered an option for future designs.  Participants even noted that the usage of the shutter as reassuring as pasting up a laptop camera (laptop comparison, n=4), which is common practice.        \u00a7.\u00a7 User Views on Trustworthiness  In contrast, participants also expressed technology scepticism, particularly that the system might secretly record audio (concerns:audio, n=5) or malfunction (concerns:malfunction, n=4).   With the increasing power of deep neural networks malfunctions, system failures, or inaccuracies will be addressable in the future, interaction designers will have to address this fear of \u201cbeing invisibly audio-recorded\u201d.  A lack of knowledge about eye tracking on both the user's and the bystander's side might even back this misconception.  Therefore, future systems using eye tracking for context recognition will have to clearly communicate their modus operandi.        \u00a7.\u00a7 Perceived Privacy of Eye Tracking  The majority of participants claimed to have no privacy concerns about smart glasses with integrated eye tracking functionality:  \u201cI do see no threat to my privacy or the like from tracking my eye movements; this [the eye tracking] would rather be something which could offer a certain comfort.\u201d\u00a0(P11) Only two participants expressed  about their privacy, e.g., due to fearing eye-based emotion recognition\u00a0(P3)", "statisticType": "other", "record": {"pval": "3"}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "In other words, to maximize accessibility, it is crucial to include a table view of the data in addition to other forms of novel interaction.     Prior exposure to data analysis and representations increases the efficacy of spatial representations.  Participants who had experience conducting data analysis or reading tactile graphs/maps were able to easily develop a spatial understanding of how each prototype worked.  Five participants (P2\u20134, 11, 13) made direct connections between the  and  prototypes, and the tactile graphs they encountered in school.  Three participants (P2, 11, 12) found their software engineering experience made it easier to understand and navigate the prototypes' hierarchical structure.  Previous literature on tactile mapping has also shown how developing tactile graphical literacy is crucial for building spatial knowledge, but they emphasize that it is not a sufficient for being able to conduct and understand data analysis. <cit.> Since our participants already had an existing spatial framework, it became easier to explain how a prototype might work using their prior experience as a benchmark, which has been corroborated by similar studies in tactile cartography. <cit.> Importantly, our participants were able to find specific origin points that they could return to in order to navigate the different branches of the tree, which would be further aided with help menus and mini-tutorials to understand the keyboard shortcuts (P2)", "statisticType": "other", "record": {"pval": "2"}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

The major challenge seems to be understanding where to place the end-effector.   As introduced in the earlier section,   users can place the end-effector either on transformable part (as in the piggy-bank model, piggybank) or on the static part (as in the spatula example, spatula), but  some users have difficulties in determining which of these two approaches to use.    \u201c  I can try either one to decide which is right\u201d  RPLUS MATCH .    Participants also had difficulties in understanding how a transformable will be anchored, where the base is.    For example, P1 selected only the middle part of the spatula handle in the first trial, thinking she needs to leave the top part to serve as the base that anchors the spatula while stirring.  Another participant also questioned \u201cIf I specify the middle part, will the top part move with it?\u201d (P8)", "statisticType": "other", "record": {"pval": "8"}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}
{"position": null, "sentence": "I understood it after couple of examples though!\u201d (P2)", "statisticType": "other", "record": {"pval": "2"}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "I understood it after couple of examples though!\u201d  RPLUS MATCH .  Such confusion was partial result of our design choice, abstracting away low-level details for users, while allowing them to rapidly explore different designs and see results, so to iterate on their earlier decision (where to place the base/end-effector).  We can also support users to explore different possibilities simultaneously to choose between different results.                        \u00a7 DISCUSSION, LIMITATIONS & FUTURE WORK   Scale of Mechanism In order to embed motors, Romeo currently requires the input 3D models have sufficient volume to house the motors in each link.     Further, the scale of an input 3D model also determines the possible range of movement of a robotic arm transformed from part of the object.  As a next step, Romeo can support automtically scaling a 3D model to meet both the requirements of housing motors and accommodating sufficiently large workspace, while estimating the printing time/cost to help users make an informed decision whether to use the scaled model.   selects too small parts to embed transformable mechanisms, as also questioned by one of our participant: \u201cIf I only want to transform ears, will that be too small?\u201d (P7)", "statisticType": "other", "record": {"pval": "7"}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "To simulate this and capture the variations, we augment the original audio breathing events using various pitch shifts and speed changes.               * Pitch shift: We consider 15 different pitch shifts ranging from -3.5 to 3.5 with 0.5 increments        * Speed change: We consider seven speed changes ranging from .25x to 2x times the speed of an original clip with an increment of .25x, skipping 1x since that would represent the original clip, which we have already included as a pitch shift with value 0.        * Noise Superposition: We consider 10 randomly picked vacuum  and washing machine sound clips, obtained from 0pt7ex the environmental sound classification dataset\u00a0<cit.>, as background noises to modify original breathing event clips with eight different signal-to-noise ratio levels ranging from 0.000110^-4 to 1000010^4, incremented by magnitudes of 10 while skipping 1.   Thereby, each original breathing clip is modified 102 times.       \u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014-  .325     < g r a p h i c s >  Top 25 heart rate and gait features selected (top 20 green bars are used for modeling) using the SelectKBest approach.   \u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014-  ***  Summary of features selected from different biometrics    Biometrics     Selector (parameters)     Selected features   Heart rate     SelectKBest (K = 10)     p25, \u03bc, rss, rms, max, Mdn, p75, \u03ba, \u03b3, P  Heart rate and gait     SelectFromModel (p = 0.90)", "statisticType": "other", "record": {"pval": "0.90"}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "The questions can be found in the supplementary materials.   After finishing 5 GIFs, they were asked to fill out a short demographic form.   Data collection.  To avoid viewers' prior knowledge influencing the results, we asked whether they have seen any of the GIFs before the questionnaire.  However, we did not want this question to influence participants' behaviors during the study.  Thus, we still asked them to complete the questions, but did not consider their responses in our analysis.  Finally, we had an average of 23.8 responses per GIF (SD: 3.5; total 476 responses for 20 GIFs) and the average accuracy across all questions and GIFs was 60.1%.    Three types of data from the questionnaire were further analyzed:  (1) accuracy from multiple-choice comprehension questions;  (2) subjective scores of viewers' understandings; and (3) qualitative feedback about influencing design factors.        \u00a7.\u00a7 Findings: What Makes a Data-GIF Understandable?   The goal of this analysis is to find the contributing design factors and validate the hypothesis.  We follow the similar statistical analysis method as Borkin et al. <cit.> and evaluates the statistical significance of the understandability with different design factors.  In our work, understanding is measured as the accuracy of multi-choice questions in the questionnaire about the GIF content.  As the accuracy scores in our data are not normally distributed, we use Kruskal-Wallis test for each design factor.  Furthermore, we use Wilcoxon two-sided test for the pair-wise comparison within each factor, and consider Bonferroni correction for multiple comparisons.  We report the sample means and 95% confidence intervals in Fig. <ref>.         Visualization Types As shown in Fig. <ref>, we observe a significant difference between the understanding of data-GIFs and chart types (p0.05)", "statisticType": "other", "record": {"pval": "0.05"}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

Context Preservation We find there is a statistically significant effect of context preservation techniques on the understanding of data-GIFs  RPLUS MATCH .  However, through pairwise comparison, we cannot find a context preservation design significantly better than the others  RPLUS MATCH , which also rejects H-Context.  There are no obvious differences in accuracy for no context preservation, baseline, and long exposure (mean=.60, .60, .61, respectively), while overview presents the lowest mean accuracy (mean=.46).   It indicates that inappropriate context design could be even worse than no context preservation, since it requires attention and efforts for viewers to notice and interpret the preserved context.  However, the duration of a data-GIF could be short, thus making it hard for viewers to perceive them all at once.  Especially for overview, if viewers could not notice it at first glance, it could not play the expected roles (i.e., presenting data summary), since viewers already see all the data before they realized the overview design. {"position": null, "sentence": "Given n noisy labels for this object, such that each noisy label is correct with a known probability a, the goal is to estimate the parameter q.  \t \tAccording to the LA-model, the unknown parameter q is estimated by the posterior probability of label 1 for the object: \t     q\u0302^ LA(n_1) := r a^n_1(1 -a)^n - n_1/r a^n_1 (1 -a)^n - n_1 + (1 - r)(1 -a)^n_1 a^n - n_1,  \twhere r is the prior probability of label 1 (common for all objects) and n_1 is the value of the random variable N_1, which is the number of ones among n noisy labels. \t \t\tThe posterior probability of label 1 obtained under the L-assumption is neither unbiased, nor consistent estimate of the true probability q underlying the generative process for the DA-model. \t \t \t\tThe posterior probability of label 1 for the object is \t\t     q\u0302^ LA(n_1) := r a^n_1(1 -a)^n - n_1/r a^n_1 (1 -a)^n - n_1 + (1 - r)(1 -a)^n_1 a^n - n_1,  \t\twhere r is the prior probability of label 1 (common for all objects) and n_1 is the value of the random variable N_1, which is the number of ones among n noisy labels. \t\t \t\tThe generative process based on the D-assumption defines the following distribution over the number of ones n_1: \t\t     ^ DA(N_1= n_1 | N = n) := n  n_1 [q a + (1 - q)(1 -a)]^n_1[q(1 -a) +(1 - q)a]^n - n_1.  \t\tConsider the expectation of q\u0302^ LA with respect to this distribution: \t\t     (q\u0302^ LA) := \u2211_n_1 = 0^n q\u0302^ LA(n_1) ^ DA(N_1= n_1 | N = n )          \t\t\t= \u2211_n_1 = 0^n [n  n_1[q a + (1 - q)(1 -a)]^n_1[q(1 -a) +(1 - q)a]^n - n_1/r a^n_1 (1 -a)^n - n_1 + (1 - r)(1 -a)^n_1 a^n - n_1 r a^n_1(1 -a)^n - n_1]  \t\t \t\tTo demonstrate that this is a biased estimate of the true parameter q, evaluate this expression as a function of q for different values of a and the uniform prior r = 0.5", "statisticType": "other", "record": {"pval": null}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "Figure\u00a0<ref>, showing the dependence of the expected value for q\u0302^ LA from q, confirms that q\u0302^ LA is a biased estimate for q. \t\t \t\t \t\t\t  \t\t\t\t     < g r a p h i c s >  \t\t\t\tThe expected values for q\u0302^ LA given by (<ref>) as a function of q for different number of noisy labels n, different values of a, and the uniform prior r = 0.5", "statisticType": "other", "record": {"pval": null}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}
